<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/sarah-palin-takes-on-the-new-york-times-in-newsroom-showdown?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Sarah Palin v. the New York Times
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/sarah-palin-takes-on-the-new-york-times-in-newsroom-showdown?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Sarah Palin" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/b9ee37e6202cec9570c3a3818ecb8ab5600f01ad-3000x2000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Gary Miller/FilmMagic</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A blockbuster <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/sarah-palin-set-battle-new-york-times-defamation-trial-2022-01-23/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">First Amendment trial</a> that pits former Alaska governor and VP nominee Sarah Palin against the US’ most iconic news source, the New York Times, will begin today.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The backstory</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In 2017, following a shooting at a practice session for the Congressional Baseball Game for Charity, the NYT ran an <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/14/opinion/steve-scalise-congress-shot-alexandria-virginia.html?_r=0" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">editorial</a> that established a connection between an ad produced by Sarah Palin’s political action committee (PAC) and another mass shooting, one in Arizona in 2011 that killed six and wounded Democratic Congresswoman Gabby Giffords. “The link to political incitement was clear,” the editorial board wrote.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That, plus another assertion that Palin’s PAC circulated a map that put Giffords and 19 other Dems under stylized crosshairs, was just not true. The NYT quickly issued corrections and tweeted an apology—but didn’t mention Palin.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Palin sued the paper less than two weeks later, accusing it of defaming her and seeking unspecified damages. The suit was originally dismissed but was revived later by an appeals court.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">How this trial will play out</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Palin will have an uphill battle to victory. As a public figure, she’ll have to prove that the NYT acted with “actual malice” in publishing the editorial—that is, that it knowingly meant to harm Palin with the falsehoods or included the falsehoods with “reckless disregard.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>That “actual malice” standard was established in 1964, in a </span><span><a href="https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/new_york_times_v_sullivan_(1964)?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Supreme Court ruling</a></span><span> that also involved the Times.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The NYT has said it was an honest mistake. As a spokesperson <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/22/media/sarah-palin-new-york-times-trial/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told CNN</a>, “We are deeply committed to fairness and accuracy in our journalism, and when we fall short, we correct our errors publicly, as we did in this case.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, the trial may be embarrassing to the NYT for exposing sloppy editing practices ahead of tight deadlines. In the case of this editorial, the then-editor of the Times editorial board, James Bennet, inserted the false passages at the last minute after being unsatisfied with a draft from the actual author of the column, Elizabeth Williamson.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>“The case will help demarcate the line between really bad journalism and libelous journalism,” the Washington Post’s Erik Wemple <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/01/21/sarah-palin-v-nyt-exploring-line-between-bad-journalism-libelous-journalism/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a>.</p>
</div>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/for-sanctions-on-russia-it-s-all-about-the-timing?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
For sanctions on Russia, it’s all about the timing
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/for-sanctions-on-russia-it-s-all-about-the-timing?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A man walks past a destroyed building of a former military installation in Eastern Ukraine" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e3dc2ba47f653395fe3823bb3e2b46a4cca46ab1-1024x635.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>A man walks past a destroyed building of a former military installation in eastern Ukraine. (Alexander Nemenov, AFP via Getty Images)</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Western leaders are scrambling to mount a unified response ahead of what they say is an imminent invasion of Ukraine by Russia.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One potential response is sanctions—financial penalties that countries use against each other like a parent telling their disobedient kid he’s grounded. Yesterday, Secretary of State Antony Blinken <a href="https://www.axios.com/blinken-sanctioning-russia-41450155-7aa7-4f87-a336-fdc83bd33209.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pushed back</a> on calls to slap sanctions on Russia before an invasion.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“When it comes to sanctions, the purpose of those sanctions is to deter Russian aggression,” Blinken said on CNN. “If they're triggered now, you lose the deterrent effect.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Some US lawmakers disagree. Sen. Joni Ernst (R-IA) said that sanctions need to be introduced now: “Once an invasion happens, lives are lost, you can’t go back from that,” she said.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Some history: </strong>The US has already <a href="https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2022/1/21/russia-ukraine-crisis-can-us-sanctions-sway-putins-thinking?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">slapped</a> Russia with a series of sanctions beginning in 2014, the last time Russia invaded Ukraine. More than 80% of Russian companies sampled for a study by Aalto University in Finland reported that sanctions imposed between 2014 and 2017 hurt business performance.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The UK <a href="https://www.axios.com/uk-government-kremlin-pro-russian-leader-ukraine-f6e88d6c-6d96-44e4-a426-d5d4a01832b2.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">upped</a> the urgency level even more on Saturday, when it accused Russia of hatching a plot to install a pro-Russian leader in Ukraine once it invades (Russia called the allegations “nonsense”). And last night the US State Dept. ordered family members at the US embassy to leave the country.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ For a deeper dive on Ukraine: </strong>Read Adam Tooze’s <a href="https://adamtooze.substack.com/p/chartbook-68-putins-challenge-to?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">analysis</a> of Russia’s geopolitical strategy.</p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CRYPTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/new-york-city-mayor-eric-adams-said-he-would-convert-first-paycheck-into-crypto?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Crypto jungle where dreams are made of
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/new-york-city-mayor-eric-adams-said-he-would-convert-first-paycheck-into-crypto?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A Coinbase sign in Times Square " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/67c2a7ce21e8a9443c0accdf5726c07de51ae4c8-1024x776.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Robert Nickelsberg/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">New York City Mayor Eric Adams received his first paycheck on Friday, but instead of spending it on a Joe’s slice, he planned to have it <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/20/nyregion/eric-adams-bitcoin-cryptocurrency.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">converted</a> to bitcoin and ethereum.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The move would partially fulfill a promise by Adams to convert his first three paychecks into crypto, and highlights his PR push to turn the Big Apple into the “center of cryptocurrency and other financial innovations.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But as Tom Brady and Aaron Rodgers learned this weekend, the competition isn’t backing down. Touting <em>his</em> city as the next crypto capital, Miami Mayor Francis Suarez has one-upped Adams and taken his last four paychecks in bitcoin. He even launched a crypto project, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/09/30/crypto-miamicoin/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">MiamiCoin</a>, to raise funds for the city and publicize its crypto efforts.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why it matters: </strong>Well, on the surface most of us don’t really care whether mayors get paid in USD or Snickers bars. But on a deeper level their efforts symbolize how mayors want to portray their cities as pro-innovation in order to attract new businesses and startups, particularly in fast-growing sectors like crypto.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And crypto is growing…fast. VC firms <a href="https://www.institutionalinvestor.com/article/b1w6r1v3pjg15s/Where-Did-VC-Money-Go-in-2021-Crypto-Startups?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">invested $32.8 billion</a> into blockchain and crypto startups in 2021, more than all previous years combined.</p>
</div>

<tr>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/key-performance-indicators-january-24?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Key performance indicators
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/key-performance-indicators-january-24?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A package of weed gummies" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/201568d42d03da6593b8f11d9fc2362afc35a9df-1024x671.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Erin Clark/The Boston Globe via Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Massachusetts, where stores have been selling recreational marijuana since 2018, has <a href="https://www.wcvb.com/article/massachusetts-marijuana-excise-tax-revenue-exceeds-alcohol-for-first-time/38834509?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew#" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">collected</a> more excise taxes from cannabis sales than from alcohol for the first time ever this fiscal year, according to WCVB.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“Where is Peng Shuai?”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Don’t wear apparel with that slogan to the Australian Open or you could find yourself getting <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2022/01/23/peng-shuai-australian-open-political-messages/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">asked to leave</a>. Tournament security ejected two fans wearing messages in support of Peng Shuai, a Chinese tennis star whose safety has been questioned by the sport’s leaders, under rules that prohibit “clothing, banners, or signs that are commercial or political” on tournament grounds.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>The forgotten medieval habit of “two sleeps.” (<a href="https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20220107-the-lost-medieval-habit-of-biphasic-sleep?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">BBC News</a>)</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CALENDAR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/the-week-ahead-january-24?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
The (very busy) week ahead
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>

<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/the-week-ahead-january-24?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A hawk standing on top of the Federal Reserve building " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/bfe4676b86845cf573a14dc00bbd8854c6788361-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Illustration: Francis Scialabba, Photos: <a href="https://unsplash.com/@joshuadan">Joshua Daniel</a>/Unsplash, Rudy Sulgan/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Fed meeting: </strong>Federal Reserve officials will get together on Tuesday and Wednesday against the backdrop of quaking markets. No major announcements are expected, but investors will want to hear an update on Chair Jerome Powell’s views on inflation. This Fed meeting will likely be the last before an anticipated interest rate hike in March.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Earnings: </strong>A blizzard of companies will deliver some fresh Q4 financial powder this week, including nearly half of the Dow’s 30 giants (American Express, 3M, IBM, and more) and tech heavyweights such as Apple, Microsoft, and Tesla.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Tax szn: </strong>The income tax filing season opens today and government officials warn it could be <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/tax-season-2022-IRS-delays-ahead?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bumpy</a> due to a depleted IRS. The Treasury says to file early, file online, and request your refund via direct deposit to avoid the worst headaches. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else:</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-gilded-age-is-even-more-fun-than-downton-abbey?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Gilded Age</em></a></span><span>, a period drama from the creator of </span><span><em>Downton Abbey</em></span><span>, premieres today on HBO.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Australian Open’s women’s and men’s singles finals will take place Friday and Saturday ET, respectively.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Today is National Compliment Day, which reminds me—your new haircut looks great.</span></li>
</ul>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GAMES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="#">
<font color="#000000">
The puzzle section
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Turntable: </strong>With word games having a moment, now’s the time to hop on the bandwagon. Try our word game, Turntable, <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/23/turntable-january-24?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here</a>.</p>

style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGary Miller/FilmMagic\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA blockbuster \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/us/sarah-palin-set-battle-new-york-times-defamation-trial-2022-01-23/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFirst Amendment trial\u003c/a\u003e that pits former Alaska governor and VP nominee Sarah Palin against the US’ most iconic news source, the New York Times, will begin today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe backstory\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn 2017, following a shooting at a practice session for the Congressional Baseball Game for Charity, the NYT ran an \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/14/opinion/steve-scalise-congress-shot-alexandria-virginia.html?_r=0\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eeditorial\u003c/a\u003e that established a connection between an ad produced by Sarah Palin’s political action committee (PAC) and another mass shooting, one in Arizona in 2011 that killed six and wounded Democratic Congresswoman Gabby Giffords. “The link to political incitement was clear,” the editorial board wrote.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat, plus another assertion that Palin’s PAC circulated a map that put Giffords and 19 other Dems under stylized crosshairs, was just not true. The NYT quickly issued corrections and tweeted an apology—but didn’t mention Palin.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePalin sued the paper less than two weeks later, accusing it of defaming her and seeking unspecified damages. The suit was originally dismissed but was revived later by an appeals court.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eHow this trial will play out\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePalin will have an uphill battle to victory. As a public figure, she’ll have to prove that the NYT acted with “actual malice” in publishing the editorial—that is, that it knowingly meant to harm Palin with the falsehoods or included the falsehoods with “reckless disregard.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThat “actual malice” standard was established in 1964, in a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/new_york_times_v_sullivan_(1964)?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSupreme Court ruling\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e that also involved the Times.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe NYT has said it was an honest mistake. As a spokesperson \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/22/media/sarah-palin-new-york-times-trial/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold CNN\u003c/a\u003e, “We are deeply committed to fairness and accuracy in our journalism, and when we fall short, we correct our errors publicly, as we did in this case.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, the trial may be embarrassing to the NYT for exposing sloppy editing practices ahead of tight deadlines. In the case of this editorial, the then-editor of the Times editorial board, James Bennet, inserted the false passages at the last minute after being unsatisfied with a draft from the actual author of the column, Elizabeth Williamson.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003e“The case will help demarcate the line between really bad journalism and libelous journalism,” the Washington Post’s Erik Wemple \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/01/21/sarah-palin-v-nyt-exploring-line-between-bad-journalism-libelous-journalism/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nFor sanctions on Russia, it’s all about the timing\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A man walks past a destroyed building of a former military installation in Eastern Ukraine\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e3dc2ba47f653395fe3823bb3e2b46a4cca46ab1-1024x635.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eA man walks past a destroyed building of a former military installation in eastern Ukraine. (Alexander Nemenov, AFP via Getty Images)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWestern leaders are scrambling to mount a unified response ahead of what they say is an imminent invasion of Ukraine by Russia.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne potential response is sanctions—financial penalties that countries use against each other like a parent telling their disobedient kid he’s grounded. Yesterday, Secretary of State Antony Blinken \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/blinken-sanctioning-russia-41450155-7aa7-4f87-a336-fdc83bd33209.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epushed back\u003c/a\u003e on calls to slap sanctions on Russia before an invasion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“When it comes to sanctions, the purpose of those sanctions is to deter Russian aggression,” Blinken said on CNN. “If they're triggered now, you lose the deterrent effect.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome US lawmakers disagree. Sen. Joni Ernst (R-IA) said that sanctions need to be introduced now: “Once an invasion happens, lives are lost, you can’t go back from that,” she said.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSome history: \u003c/strong\u003eThe US has already \u003ca href=\"https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2022/1/21/russia-ukraine-crisis-can-us-sanctions-sway-putins-thinking?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eslapped\u003c/a\u003e Russia with a series of sanctions beginning in 2014, the last time Russia invaded Ukraine. More than 80% of Russian companies sampled for a study by Aalto University in Finland reported that sanctions imposed between 2014 and 2017 hurt business performance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe UK \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/uk-government-kremlin-pro-russian-leader-ukraine-f6e88d6c-6d96-44e4-a426-d5d4a01832b2.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eupped\u003c/a\u003e the urgency level even more on Saturday, when it accused Russia of hatching a plot to install a pro-Russian leader in Ukraine once it invades (Russia called the allegations “nonsense”). And last night the US State Dept. ordered family members at the US embassy to leave the country.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ For a deeper dive on Ukraine: \u003c/strong\u003eRead Adam Tooze’s \u003ca style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanalysis\u003c/a\u003e of Russia’s geopolitical strategy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNew York City Mayor Eric Adams received his first paycheck on Friday, but instead of spending it on a Joe’s slice, he planned to have it \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/20/nyregion/eric-adams-bitcoin-cryptocurrency.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econverted\u003c/a\u003e to bitcoin and ethereum.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe move would partially fulfill a promise by Adams to convert his first three paychecks into crypto, and highlights his PR push to turn the Big Apple into the “center of cryptocurrency and other financial innovations.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut as Tom Brady and Aaron Rodgers learned this weekend, the competition isn’t backing down. Touting \u003cem\u003ehis\u003c/em\u003e city as the next crypto capital, Miami Mayor Francis Suarez has one-upped Adams and taken his last four paychecks in bitcoin. He even launched a crypto project, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/09/30/crypto-miamicoin/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eMiamiCoin\u003c/a\u003e, to raise funds for the city and publicize its crypto efforts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy it matters: \u003c/strong\u003eWell, on the surface most of us don’t really care whether mayors get paid in USD or Snickers bars. But on a deeper level their efforts symbolize how mayors want to portray their cities as pro-innovation in order to attract new businesses and startups, particularly in fast-growing sectors like crypto.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd crypto is growing…fast. VC firms \u003ca href=\"https://www.institutionalinvestor.com/article/b1w6r1v3pjg15s/Where-Did-VC-Money-Go-in-2021-Crypto-Startups?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einvested $32.8 billion\u003c/a\u003e into blockchain and crypto startups in 2021, more
